These functions can interact in a variety of ways, butHekkert et al. (2007) identified three likely "motors of change" depicted in Figure7. One trigger that can start a virtuous cycle of innovation is Guidance of the Search, particularly government goals that are set after identifying a social problem, such as environmental damage, in an attempt to correct or limit the problem. Once the goals are set, new resources might be made available which can lead to Knowledge Development and increasing expectations about technological options (see Motor C).Another trigger can be lobbying by entrepreneurs (Support from Advocacy Coalitions) in an effort to make economic conditions more favorable for technology development. Lobbying focused on increased R&D resources might lead to higher expectations (Motor B) whereas lobbying for Market Formation (Motor A) can help level the playing field, boosting

States could already be considered a success. As a percentage of total distillate fuel oils (diesel fuels and fuel oils) produced in the US, the amount of biodiesel produced annually has increased significantly over the past decade. In 2001 biodiesel made up 0.02% of the distillate fuel oil market with 9 million gallons of biodiesel being produced compared to 38 billion gallons of total distillate fuel oil (US EIA, 2007). In the first ten months of 2011 biodiesel accounted for 1.34% of the distillate fuel oil market, an increase of almost two orders of magnitude as production volumes increased to 655 million gallons and 49 billion gallons for biodiesel and distillate fuel oil, respectively (US EIA, 2012c). Another measure of success is that biodiesel is now independent of subsidies as the incentives included in the 2005 EPAct expired in2008 and 2009.

Development 2). The next major development was in 1970 when Western Electric patented an anti-reflective coating for solar cells (Entrepreneurial Activity 4, Knowledge Development 3) (US DOE, 2012). Starting in the mid-1970s, PV devices were increasingly used for remote commercial power applications such as highway call boxes and railroad crossing signals (Entrepreneurial Activity 5)(Dracker & De Laquil, 1996). Much of the early development of solar technology was supported by government. The National Science Foundation and the Energy Research and Development Administration, which later became part of DOE, led government R&D efforts (Knowledge Development 4). Private industry efforts were also significant, but in the 1970s and early 1980s a large percentage of total funding was from the federal government and focused on demonstration projects to prove technical feasibility (Entrepreneurial Activity 6, Resource Mobilization 1) (Dracker & De Laquil, 1996). (Because funding came from government this falls under Resource Mobilization, but because the demonstration projects are carried out by industry and have a commercial aim it is also Entrepreneurial Activity.) Academic institutions were also contributing to research efforts with the University of Delaware opening the first laboratory dedicated to solar R&D in 1972, focusing particularly on thin-film PV cells (Knowledge Development 5). That same year, solar PV cells became the primary power source for approximately 1,000 US and Russian spacecraft (Market Formation 1) (US DOE, 2012). The late 1970s and early 1980s saw continued developments in the formation of government bodies relevant to energy technology research and in PV technology itself. In 1977 in the aftermath of the OPEC oil embargo, the Department of Energy (DOE) and the National Renewable Energy Laboratory were established. Shortly after, DOE promoted solar PV research in multiple national laboratories (Guidance of the Search 1, Knowledge Development 6).

The task force consisted of representatives from the Nevada governor's office, state organizations, labor unions, financial institutions, and the solar industry (Knowledge Diffusion 2). figure.figDesc: RFS was initially introduced in the 2005 Energy Policy Act, but it was reformulated into the more aggressive version it is in today by the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 (40 CFR 80 Subpart M). It requires that on an annual average basis the transportation fuel Under the current law, only cellulosic biofuel produced after 2008 and before 2013 is eligible (US DOE EERE, 2011a). This tax credit would not apply to algal biodiesel since algae is not considered a qualified feedstock.Tax credit policies mainly focus on achieving cost competitiveness with conventional fuels once a fuel is in production. There have been multiple attempts to pass legislation that would offer such incentives to algal fuels, but none have been passed. The Algae-based Renewable Fuel Promotion Act has been introduced in Congress three times, in2009, 2010, and

note.p: sold in the United States contains at least the applicable volume of renewable fuel set for that year. The RFS began in 2006 and by 2022 36 billion gallons per year total of renewable fuels are required to be sold. There are four categories of renewable fuel: conventional renewable fuels (e.g. corn grain ethanol), cellulosic biofuels, biomass-based diesel, and other advanced biofuels. Except for conventional renewable fuels, which are capped at 15 billion gallons per year in 2015, the volume mandates for the fuels ramp up over time so that by 2022 the US is required to use 16 billion gallons per year of cellulosic biofuel, 1 billion gallons per year of biomass-based diesel, and 4 billion gallons per year of other advanced biofuels (US DOE EERE, 2011b). Algal fuel could be included in the category of biomass-based diesel or other advanced biofuels.The Cellulosic Biofuel Producer Tax Credit, created in the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008, is designed to provide incentives for advanced biofuels, but only those made from cellulose (Renewable Fuels Association, 2011). Under this tax credit, cellulosic biofuel producers may be eligible for a tax incentive up to $1.01 per gallon of cellulosic biofuel that is sold or used. If the cellulosic biofuel also qualifies for alcohol fuel tax credits, the amount is reduced to $0.46 per gallon if the biofuel is ethanol and $0.41 per gallon if it is not ethanol. 2011(S.1250, H.R.4168, and S.748, respectively). The bill would have modified the definition of cellulosic biofuel for the purposes of the Cellulosic Biofuel Producer Tax Credit and Special Depreciation Allowance for Cellulosic Biofuel Plant Property to mean any liquid fuel which is derived solely by, or from, any lignocellulosic or hemicellulosic matter that is available on a renewable or recurring basis and any cultivated algae, cyanobacteria, or lemna. figure.figDesc: succinctly summarize Ruttan's induced innovation model:In brief, this theory holds that the technology in use in any economic sectorand, given enough time, the direction of development and researchresponds to changes in the market, for example to price signals by minimizing the use of expensive inputs and maximizing the use of inexpensive ones. By extension, the model would predict that technology and technological innovation would also respond to the policy environment, for example by improving worker and product safety and decreasing pollution as policies in these areas are tightened. such as wind turbines. Third is adaptation through technologies that require significant investment and development before full-scale implementation and deployment is possible. The fourth and most drastic category of response is long-term investments by both the public and private sectors in research, development, and demonstration of new technologies

note.p: This theory is based on the idea that new products use existing technologies to meet new market demands rather than building on basic research such that incremental gains are achieved rather than radical changes in technology. As the market for the new product develops, competitors enter and producers are forced to improve the product and lower the cost. These improvements might eventually be limited by the current understandings of science and technology and require further investment in research. The model is concerned not just with the evolution of individual technologies but also with the aggregate characteristics of the technologies in use within a given branch of an economy(Weiss & Bonvillian, 2009).Weiss & Bonvillian (2009) applied the induced innovation model specifically to energy technology and stated that if the price or policy environment clearly moves toward more expensive energy, like in the 1970s, technology will respond throughout the economy. How fast the response is depends in large part on the size and rate of return of the necessary investments.The authors then categorized the varying degrees of response. The first category is quick, simple changes in behavior such as driving less and performing basic retrofits. Second is investments in capital equipment for technologies that can be quickly brought to market or are established in niche markets,

div.p: Photovoltaics Review Committee that was tasked with introducing cost-effective PV systems to military applications (Market Formation 2) (Dracker & De Laquil, 1996).

Collaborative efforts also arose out of the private sector between utilities and PV companies. The Utility PV Group (UPVG) was formed in 1992 and submitted a proposal to DOE to install 50 MW of PV systems. UPVG also worked to bring together developers of PV applications with potential buyers (Support from Advocacy Coalitions 1). At the state level, a parallel organization was formed called PVs for Utilities (Support from Advocacy Coalitions 2) (Dracker & De Laquil, 1996). Both groups focused their efforts on encouraging electric utilities to invest in large PV systems and generally increasing knowledge about PV efficiencies, costs, and technical logistics (Knowledge Diffusion 3) (Kaplan, 1999). Some utilities have also implemented solar programs of their own such as offering incentives for customers willing to be early adopters of rooftop PV systems and creating off-grid tariff systems to expand PV installations (Resource Mobilization 3) (Dracker & De Laquil, 1996).

The mid 1990s brought another increase in government initiatives to promote solar power. In 1996 the National Center for Photovoltaics was created to better integrate research efforts occurring at national laboratories (Knowledge Diffusion 4). In 1997 President Clinton Looking at the importance of each function in the story constructed from the literature, there are four that seem to be most prevalent in the innovation process: Entrepreneurial Activity, Knowledge Development, Guidance of the Search, and Resource Mobilization. Some of the events indicative of these functions overlapped into more than one category, however (e.g. Hoffman Electronics development and sale of a PV cell with 10% efficiency is both Entrepreneurial Activity and Knowledge Development), emphasizing the difficulty with relying only on the count of events indicating a particular TIS function in determining importance to the unsuccessful, but it does indicate that there is still progress to be made in achieving cost competitiveness with other energy sources.

Based on the stories found in the literature of these innovation processes, a subset of the TIS functions were identified as being more influential. For first generation biodiesel Guidance of the Search, Market Formation, and Resource Mobilization seemed to be the biggest drivers throughout, but Entrepreneurial Activity and Support from Advocacy Coalitions were influential factors in the beginning. For solar PV Entrepreneurial Activity, Knowledge Development, Guidance of the Search, and Resource Mobilization seemed to be the most influential (Table 9). The ones that were common to both are Entrepreneurial Activity, Guidance of the Search, and Resource Mobilization. When completely boiled down, the short stories of the case studies match: industry saw an opportunity for a new commercial product (Entrepreneurial Activity) and changing national priorities (Guidance of the Search) bolstered public interest in the new product which government then supported through policy targets and subsidies (Guidance of the Search and Resource Mobilization).
